content: * *Hossan Leong** ([simplified Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 梁荣耀; [traditional Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 梁榮耀; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Liáng Róngyào*; born 10 July 1969) is a Singaporean stage and screen actor, television host, [radio deejay](/wiki/Radio_deejay) and comedian. ## Personal life He was born 10 July 1969 in Singapore, Leong was educated at [Anglo-Chinese School](/wiki/Anglo-Chinese_School) and [Anglo-Chinese Junior College](/wiki/Anglo-Chinese_Junior_College) and studied electronics at the French-Singapore Institute, which was since transferred in February 1993 and currently part of [Nanyang Polytechnic](/wiki/Nanyang_Polytechnic). He is of Cantonese descent and speaks Cantonese. ## Career Leong started his showbiz career as a television actor and starred in several [TCS](/wiki/Television_Corporation_of_Singapore) English and Chinese language dramas during the 1990s before diversifying into theatre and comedy. Having learned French while studying at the French-Singapore Institute, he is fluent in the language and worked with the [Alliance française](/wiki/Alliance_fran%C3%A7aise) for some time. In 2010 he was conferred the [Chevalier](/wiki/Ordre_des_Arts_et_des_Lettres) de l'[Ordre des Arts et des Lettres](/wiki/Ordre_des_Arts_et_des_Lettres) by the French Ministry of Culture. Besides acting, Leong was also a radio deejay with [Gold 90.5FM](/wiki/Gold_90.5FM). He came under media spotlight after he was reportedly censured for announcing the disruption to the [Circle Line](/wiki/Circle_Line_(Singapore)) train services on the morning of 14 December 2011 as [SMRT](/wiki/SMRT_Corporation) had not issued an official statement. As host of the weekday breakfast show, Leong had a practice of reading out user comments on Twitter account regarding public transport and traffic conditions. The station's response triggered massive criticism from many netizens and listeners already angered by SMRT's delay in announcing the disruption, which took place during the early morning "rush hour" and affected thousands.
